author: Ground News
title: Ground News - The secret shrine in Worcester where Catholic martyr saint met horrible end
text:
Summary by Ground News The Venerable John Wall was hanged, drawn and quartered in Red Hill in Worcester 1679. This is also the site where the Jesuit Priest Edward Oldcorne suffered the same fate on April 7, 1606. The medieval moated manor of Harvington Hall, which has strong links to John Wall, contains more priest holes or hides than any other house in England. Share menu More

author: Tracy Lopez
title: 9to5Rewards: Last Chance to Win a Google Pixel 8 from Formovie (+4K Ultra Short Throw Projector Deal)
text: There's still time to join the giveaway with our friends at Formovie to win Google's new Pixel 8. For a limited time, you can also score up to $800 off the new Formovie Theater, a premium Android TV-powered 4K ultra short throw projector. Head below to take a closer look and enter the giveaway now. Formovie Theater Premium 4K Ultra Short Throw Projector The FormaMovie Theater with Built-In Android TV, which we reviewed earlier this year, gives you the ability to add a 150-inch, high-quality display to your living room. The Theater is a short-throw projector, which means you don't have to mount it on a wall or ceiling. Rather, all you need is a table and a wall (and ideally a screen, too). The projector can display up to 150 inches on the wall with minimal impact on your living room. And with 4K HDR support, everything will look crisp and vibrant, just like it does on a traditional TV. It even supports Dolby Vision, HDR10, and HDR10+ for a great movie theater-like experience. And everything is displayed with super-accurate colors at 107% of the Rec.2020 color gamut standard. Ahead of the holidays, Formuvi is offering $500 off theaters using the Formuvi coupon code best500 When checking out at the Formovie store. You may get an even better deal – and a excess Enhanced Experience – Pairing it with the Formovie 150-inch ALR screen, the bundle is currently discounted by $800. how to enter: For a chance to win a Google Pixel 8, enter your name and email below to sign up for Formovie and 9to5Google's newsletter (one submission per email address). Be sure to share our giveaway on Facebook or Facebook pixel 8 cheap FTC: We use auto affiliate links that generate income. More.

author: Mary Walrath-Holdridge
title: Kathleen Wilson's Minnesota dentist did 30 procedures at once: lawsuit
text: 20 fillings, 4 root canals, 8 crowns in one visit add up to lawsuit for Minnesota dentist [Mary Walrath-Holdridge](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/12093029002/mary-walrathholdridge/) A Minnesota dentist has become the subject of a malpractice lawsuit after his patient accused him of "disfiguring" her. The civil lawsuit was filed in Hennepin County, Minnesota last week by Kathleen Wilson, who alleged Dr. Kevin Molldrem and [Molldrem Family Dentistry](https://molldremdentistry.com/) caused her significant injury that is still being corrected. According to the suit, Molldrem performed more than 30 producers on Wilson in a single July 2020 visit, doing eight crowns, four root canals and 20 fillings in one go. The lawsuit alleges that the dentist "perform[ed] this work improperly," resulting in pain and suffering, embarrassment, emotional distress, and disfigurement. Molldrem was likewise accused of using improper levels of anesthesia during the procedures and falsifying medical records to cover it up. Treatment called 'inconceivable' “It is inconceivable that Dr. Molldrem could have prepared and placed 8 crowns under these circumstances in the time allotted, not to mention the additional 20 restorations,” wrote [Dr. Avrum Goldstein,](https://www.seakexperts.com/members/4827-avrum-r-goldstein) a dentist and expert witness brought on by Wilson's attorney, in an affidavit. Goldstein, who is a faculty member at [NOVA Southeastern University](https://dental.nova.edu/aboutus/faculty/goldstein-avrum%20.html?_gl=1*1kqtqxq*_gcl_au*ODA4NzUxNTA1LjE3MDM3OTc5MjI.), also wrote that Wilson had been correctly diagnosed as having a "rare condition" causing decay in almost all of her teeth, but Mollderm's course of action was not a proper form of treatment. "[Wilson’s] required a slow, thoughtful, careful and measured response to her disease,” he said in his report. “Trying to fill every hole in every tooth in her mouth in one visit is not only the antithesis of what was indicated, it is not humanly possible to achieve in an effective or constructive manner.” Doctors remove wrong organ from man: [They opened him up to remove his appendix. They mistakenly took out much more, lawsuit says.](/story/news/health/2023/11/07/doctors-accidentally-remove-wrong-organ-surgery/71487292007/) The lawsuit also accused Mollderm of tampering with medical records to falsify the amount of anesthesia that was reportedly used, which in reality was nearly double the standard number of units, according to court paperwork. According to Goldstein, the maximum dose of anesthesia given in three hours should not exceed 490 mg, but Molldrem's records show he gave Wilson 960 mg. “Any negative cardiovascular or central nervous system outcomes could be tied to the local anesthetic overdose," he wrote. Wilson said in the suit that she has since had to have the dental work completely redone by other dentists to repair Molldrem’s “negligent work," an ongoing process that has caused her to lose income and rack up medical bills on top of enduring pain, suffering and embarrassment. She is seeking more than $50,000 in damages. Wilson's attorney and Molldrem did not immediately respond to request for comment.

author: @ABC21WPTA
title: $1M winning lottery ticket sold in Kendallville claimed 5 hours before deadline
text:
$1M winning lottery ticket sold in Kendallville claimed 5 hours before deadline
The winner had until 4:30 p.m. ET Thursday to claim their prize
KENDALLVILLE, Ind. (WPTA) - With five hours to spare, the couple who bought a $1 million winning lottery ticket in Kendallville claimed their prize.
The ticket, which matched all five white balls for the June 29 drawing, was bought at Kendallville Finish Line, at 620 Professional Way. The winning Powerball numbers for that drawing were: 26-51-54-61-69 with the Powerball of 25.
Upon claiming the ticket, they said it was “an emotional day” for them both.
They told Hoosier lottery officials they had seen news coverage and signage about the unclaimed ticket beginning about a month ago and began searching. The couple said they do not visit the gas station frequently and were unsure if they had purchased a ticket for that specific Powerball drawing.
The first search was unsuccessful, but on Wednesday, they woke up at 4 a.m. to search again – including deep between their car seats. There, they found their winning ticket.
All prizes must be claimed within 180 days of the drawing. Hoosier Lottery encourages those with winning tickets to ensure their ticket is in a secure place, consider meeting with a financial advisor and contact Hoosier Lottery customer service at 1-800-955-6886 for specific claim instructions.
The Powerball jackpot is an estimated $145 million for Saturday, Dec. 28. Overall odds are 1 in 25, per Hoosier Lottery.
Watch our [previous report](https://www.21alivenews.com/2024/12/07/1-million-winning-powerball-ticket-sold-kendallville-expire-soon/) below.
To be the first to get the latest breaking news alerts, download the 21Alive News App.
Download for both iPhone and Android devices can be found [here](https://www.21alivenews.com/page/get-the-new-abc-21-news-app-today/).
